716802f-a.text:
Bowling Green 1835
Photograph by Brown Brothers
220 West 42nd St.
New York City

723426f.title: Manhattan: State Street - Bowling Green Row
723426f.text:
State Street, east side, south from Bowling Green Row to Pearl Street, showing a row of fashionable homes facing on Battery Park (right). Shown in the foreground, is No. 7 Bowling 9reen, at the S.E. corner of State Street. The farthest building shown, is Stewart's Store, (predecessor to John Wanamaker in the Department Store line), which occupied the block between Bridge and Pearl Streets. Stephen Whitney resided in one of the houses facing Bowling Green. Today (1937), the U.S. Custom House rises here on the area shown in the foreground, with the 12-story Battery Park Building
(former Stewart site) at its rear.
About 1860.
Ewing Galloway.
A4ae
ww~
723426f.folder: State Street & Bowling Green Row, Manhattan, NY

716806f-b.text:
1-Bowling Green, a northward view up Broadway from "Steamship Row", showing a view of New York's first park. Note the iron railing around same and the lanterns thereupon. In the center is a pool and fountain.
Early views (circa l850 and 61) show this latter feature and which in subsequent views (1864) is absent, the pool remained. The last date given is that of Produce Exchange Building construction, replacing the buildings on the right.
To the left on Broadway, appear ovate shaped sewer pipes and a partial excavation for same. These were introduced in 1860 and were 4x2.8 feet in diameter. In 1804 vitrified pipe was first laid. Across the foreground are suspended electric wires and at the extreme right is an old street illuminating gas lamp.
For dedication ceremony (April 6, 1938) see New York City newspapers for February and March. Views similar to this are in these files and in a volume of newspaper clippings titled "New York City Views" American History Division - Room 300 New York Public Library, several of which are credited to
the Consolidated Edison Company.
Between 1861 and 1864
Rockwood Photo
E--Broadway north from Bowling Green
Thaddeus Wilderson  about 1900
522 W. 145th Street
New York City

716814f-a.text:
Bowling Green: New York's first park photographed southward down Broadway. This thoroughfare is on the right and Battery Park is just beyond. Buildings appearing through the trees are units of the former residences that now form "Steamship Row." Above
same, in the Upper Bay, lies Governor's Island.
About 1875
Roege, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

716976f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing mainly the westerly side of this thoroughfare and its Trinity Church at Wall Street.
1876
Roege, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

716808f.text:
Bowling Green: Two old views of the Bowling Green Park, one being north up Broadway (view 1) and the other south, across the site where the Custom House was later erected.
1880's
Views 1,2

716972f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green. Trinity Church is shown on the west side of Broadway, north of Rector Street. In the foreground, appears a Broadway street car; drawn by horses. hote gas 1ights on street and overhead wire communications.
About 1882.

W. Gray.
New York Edison Company.

716809f-a.text:
Bowling Green Park: New Yorks first park, located at the foot of Broadway. The buildings in the background are upon the west side of that thoroughfare, extending between Battery Place (left) and Morris Street (right). The Columbia Building stands at the N. W. corner of the 1atter point. To the north is the Aldrich Court.
About 1885
Gift of the Urbrock Collection

716956f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from Bowling Green and showing prominently the Seaboard National Bank (No. 18) and the Standard Oil Building (No. 26).  Subsequently,this latter corporation purchased the Bank site and erected upon same. Kings Hand book of New York, 1892, carries an account of this financial institution and a similar illustration on page 692.
1889.
Brown Brothers.

716971f-a.text:
Broadway, north from new Battery Place. In the background is Trinity Church.
1890's
views 1,2

716967f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing prominently the easterly side of this thoroughfare. On the right appears the Standard Oil Building and the adjoining Seaboard National Bank. For details and a comparative illustration see King's Handbook of New York--pages 143 and 692.
About 1895
Gift Thru New York Historical Society

716953f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing prominently on the east side (right) the 16 story Standard Oil Building, No. 26. On the left appears
the 17 story Bowling Green Building, No. 5-11.
1899
Ewing Galloway

716818f-a.text:
"The houses at Bowling Green" p.157
Pelletreau, William S.
Early New York houses with historical - genealogical notes.
New York: Prancis P. Harper, 1900.

716930f-a.text:
"Broadway, w.s. opposite Bowling Breen" p.207
Broadway, Nos.1-11
Pelletreau, William S.
Early New York houses with historical - genealogical notes.

716938f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing the foot of this important Manhattan thoroughfare. The City's first park, the Green, is in the center behind the street car. The buildings there are on the east side and were later replaced with the outstanding Standard Oil Building. At the left margin is No. 1 Broadway.
About 1900
Thomas V. Kennedy, photo
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photo. Assn.

716935f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, with Battery Place on the left, and Beaver Street on the right, and showing mainly the east side of Broadway across Bowling Green.
September 20, 1906.
Brown Brothers.

716940f.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green and showing on the extreme left, a portion of the Washington Building and on the right, a part of the Produce Exchange Building.
About 1905.
Brown Brothers.

716804f-a.text:
Bowling Green, at the foot of Broadway, showing the U. S. Custom House there, as photographed across Bowling Green Park. To the left of same is Whitehall Street. On the right is State Street and Battery Park.
1908
Copyright 1908
Geo. P. Hall & Son
Gift of Urbrock Collection

716927f.text:
No. 1 Broadway, at the N.W. corner of Battery Place, showing the dome of the Washington Building as viewed in a southward direction from the Bowling Green Building. Ihn addition appears a portion of Battery Park and the Upper Bay. This set consists of a negative and a positive.
July 27, 1920.
Irving Underhill.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.

716803f-a.text:
The Bowling Green - Manhattan Island 1920?
Fairchild Aerial Camera Corporation

This print is from Negative No. 2:
Order No. AE 629

716932f-a.text:
Broadway, north from and including Battery Place. (Standard Oil Building)
Brown Brothers.

716944f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green.
1926.
Brown Brothers.

716945f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green. The intersection shown on the right, is Beaver Street, with the 7-story Produce Building at the S.E. corner. The towered Standard Oil Co. Building (Nos. 8 to 26 Broadway) ocoupies the N.E. corner. Prominent buildings shown on the left, (west side of Broadway), and in the order of their appearance are the: Washington, Bowling Green, Cunard, Columbia, Adams, American Railway Eypress Co., Empire, Trinity
and Singer.
September 1926.
Brown Brothers.

716946f-a.text:
Broadway, north from both Battery Place and Beaver Street. (At the left is Battery P1ace and at the right is Beaver Street. This view shows Bowling Green in the centre foreground, which was originally used by the Dutch, for bowling and a drinking place, a refuge from their respective domestic havens.
About 1925.

716973f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing the start of this thoroughfare that traverses the entire island.
September 1926.
Brown Brothers.

716968f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, with Battery Place on the left, and Beaver Street on the right. Sandwiched between these building giants, is Bowling Green, the first public park in Manhattan, surrounding which stood the homes of Lord Cornwallis, Lord Howe, Sir Henry Clinton, George Washington, General Gates, Benedict Arnold, Talleyrand and other famous personages of American History. To-day (1937), we find encompassing same, the Washington, Bowling Green, and Cunard Buildings on the west side of Broadway, and facing the curved Standard Oil Co. Building. On the right, a portion of the U.S. Custom House obstructs a view of the Produce Exchange Building. The spired edifices in the background, are the Singer and Woolworth Buildings.
February 4, 1927.
New York Edison Company.

716819f-a.text:
Bowling Green and the U.S. Custom House, as viewed southward along Broadway. Shown on the right, the west side of Broadway, and in the order of their appearance are, the Cunard Building, the Bowling Green Building, the Washington Building and Battery Park. The curved building on the opposite side, is Nos. 8-26 Broadway, the Standard Oil Company Building.
February 21, 1928
N.Y. Edison Company.

716933f-a.text:
(1)
Broadway, north from Battery Place, showing at the left, the Washington Building (N.W. corner of Battery Place) and at the right the curved structure of the Standard Oil Co. (N.E. corner of Beaver Street). Note the
Woolworth Building, up Broadway.
May 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The tower atop the Standard Oil Building as viewed in a northward direction from the Produce Exchange Building. Broadway is on the left.
August 28, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

716933f-b.text:
(1)
Broadway, north from Battery Place, showing at the left, the Washington Building (N.W. corner of Battery Place) and at the right the curved structure of the Standard Oil Co. (N.E. corner of Beaver Street). Note the

716961f-b.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green (right) and showing mainly the west side (left) of same. Note the apple vendors in front of the Cunard Building. This was a feature of the early phases of the Depression. This
set consists of 2 views.
About 1930.

716961f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green (right) and showing mainly the west side (left) of same. Note the apple vendors in front of the Cunard Building. This was a feature of the early phases of the Depression. This
set consists of 2 views.
About 1930.

Broadway, north from Bowling Green, as viewed from the U. S. Custom House.
Brown Bros.  About 1935

716812f-b.text:
(1)
Bowling Green: (A small triangular plot on the northern confines of Battery Park), at the southern terminus of Broadway. Shown in the Green, and facing the Custom House, is the heroic statue of Abraham Depeyster the great-grandfather of Philip Van Cortlandt.
June 25, 1936.
P.L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing a more inclusive view southward of the west side
of Broadway.
June 25, 1936.
P.L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, and showing a closer view of the statue of Abraham Depeyster.
May 17, 1936.
P.L. Sperr.

716965f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing W.P.A. employees engaged in a street car track removal project. Note the Republican campaign banner suspended aoross Broadway, soliciting the financial and clerical workers of this district to vote for their presidential candidate, who as it eventually evolved, failed to be elected; Franklin D. Roosevelt gaining
a second term.
August 25, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

716801f-a.text:
Abraham De Peyster Statue
Bowling Green, Manhattan
Looking north on Broadway
Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer
Neg. No. 154
[Note: negative at Museum of the City of New York]
Code IB
July 23, 1936

716934f-a.text:
Broadway, at Bowling Green, viewed northward from the U. S. Custom House. Dominant on the right is the Standard Oil Building. Opposed to same are the Cunard, Columbia and Fred F. French Buildings.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "PortraIt of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

1507318-a.title: Battery Place - State Street
1507318-a.folder: Battery Place - State Street, Manhattan, NY

716569f.text:
72 Battery Place,North West corner of Broadway,to and including Greenwich Street,showing the Washington Building. Note Battery Place Station at Greenwich Street of the Sixth and Ninth Avenue Elevated. The building was completed in 1884 and is 13 stories in height.
January 1886.
Wurts Bros. General Photographers,
1368 Broadway,corner 36th St.

716810f-a.text: "Gateway to New World" Custom House is one side of opening and Internabional Mercantile Marine Building on other.

716822f-b.text:
(1) Bowling Green, east from Broadway showing "Steamship Row" and the Produce Exchange Building. The Custom House replaced the former. The decorations may be for
the Admiral Dewey Celebration.
About 1899
Thomas W. Kennedy Collection
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photographers Association
Grand Central Terminal

716823f-b.text:
Bowling Green viewed northward from Battery Place (in Views 1-2-3) showing the point where Broadway begins its existance.
Note the old horse car in view 1.
Views 2-3-4 were taken to show the completion of the track reroval by the W.P.A. This agency also rehabilitated the park
and its famous railing.
George L. Balgue  View 1: Nov. 1905
W. P. A. Photo  View 2-3-4: February 7, 1937
Five Borouths Project

716929f.text:
New home of International Mercantile & Marine Company at
1 Broadway.

716941f.text:
(1)
Nos. 1, 5-11 and 13 to 27 Broadway, west side, north from Battery Place (left) to Morris Street (right) as seen across Bowling Oreen. Twe 12-story structure on the left (No. 1) is the Washington Building. Adjacent to same is the 17-story Bowling Green Building, No. 5-11. At the S.W. corner of Morris Street is the 5-story Stevens House, No. 21-27. Across the roof of the latter appears the south side of the 12-story Columbia Building, No. 29 Broadway, at the N.W. corner
of Morris Street.
September 25, 1906.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  C7  T AE  N N  1 O
(2)
The same in a southward direction (from Morris Street to Battery Place). Note on the extreme left the Custom House under construction.
May 2, 1904.
Brown Brothers.

716942f.text:
Broadway, north from Battery Place, across Bowling Green. On left is the old-type Washington Building. In the immediate foreground is the United States Custom House under construction.
Ewing Galloway  no date

716943f-b.text:
(1)
Broadway, north from Bowling Green as viewed across Battery Park (immediate foreground) and from the station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line.
May 24, 1926.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, slightly northward.
November 23, 1932.

716821f-a.text:
(1)
Bowling Green South, east from and including State Street, to and including Broadway. Also shown is State Street, east side, south from Bowling Green South, to but not including Bridge Street. Bowling Green South was known as Steamship Row, and is now the
present site for the Custom House.
About 1885.
Brown Brothers.
(2)
The same, about forty-five years later, showing the United States Custom House with Bowling Green in the foreground. Also shown is Broadway, east side, south from but not including Beaver Street.
June 6, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A view mainly of the New York Produce Exchange Building (No. 2
Broadway), the eastern boundary of the Green.
October 13, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
